Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 62199: All Other Ambulatory Health Care Services
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: HealthSouth agreed to pay $7.9 million to resolve allegations that it overcharged Medicare and the Defense Department's TRICARE program for equipment and supplies purchased from G.G. Enterprises, a corporation owned by the parents of HealthSouth's CEO.

HealthSouth Corporation, the nation's largest provider of rehabilitative medicine services, agreed to pay the United States $325 million to settle allegations that the company defrauded Medicare and other federal healthcare programs.

HealthSouth Corporation agreed to pay the United States $14.2 million to settle allegations that the Birmingham, Ala.-based company submitted false claims to the government and paid illegal kickbacks to physicians who referred patients for care in some of its hospitals, outpatient rehabilitation clinics, and ambulatory surgery centers.

Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Info Source: Contained in data obtained on April 11, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: HealthSouth ERISA, et al v. Master Docket, et al

Description: Encompass Health Corporation (formerly known as HealthSouth Corporation), the nation's largest operator of inpatient rehabilitation facilities (IRFs), agreed to pay $48 million to resolve allegations that some of its IRFs provided inaccurate information to Medicare to maintain their status as an IRF and to earn a higher rate of reimbursement, and that some admissions to its IRFs were not medically necessary.

In a case brought by the New Mexico AG on behalf of a state pension fund and other investors, HealthSouth agreed to pay $445 million to settle allegations that it engaged in fraudulent accounting practices that caused hundreds of millions of dollars in losses to shareholders.
Info Source: Attorney General Madrid Announces Settlement in HealthSouth Securities Fraud US States News, February 23, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: Healthsouth Corp. paid $1,060,683 to settle allegations that, from 1992 to 1998, four Alaska medical clinics purchased by Healthsouth in September 1997  submitted billings for services that were not provided, kept inadequate records, submitted double billings, and committed numerous other violations of Medicaid regulations.

Info Source: HEALTHSOUTH TO PAY U.S. $4 MILLION TO SETTLE FALSE CLAIMS ALLEGATIONS, US Fed News, October 31, 2006 (via Nexis).
Texas Work Comp December Enforcements Include Fines Up to $78K, Insurance Journal, January 18, 2011 (via Nexis).

Company: HEALTHSOUTH REHABILITATION HOSPITAL AT DRAKE, LLC
NAICS Translation: 622310: Specialty (except Psychiatric and Substance Abuse) Hospitals
